top_comment.text:
We hear anywhere from 10 to 200 lies a day. And although we’ve spent much 
of our history coming up with ways to detect these lies by tracking 
physiological changes in their tellers, these methods have proved 
unreliable. Is there a more direct approach? Noah Zandan uses some famous 
examples of lying to illustrate how we might use communications science to 
analyze the lies themselves.﻿
top_comment.author: TED-Ed

comments.text:
This is useless.  All the examples of lies given are examples of people 
denying an event.  All the examples of lies are statements where people are 
denying a socially unacceptable action.

It did not give an example where one was truthfully refuting an accusation. 
 Nor did it give an example where one was falsely bragging about an action 
which society considers praise worthy..  

In other words, there are other distinguishing characteristics between the 
two different sets of examples of speech patterns besides truthfulness.
comments.author: Mark Stuber

comments.text:
A lot of these examples are pre-crafted.  No one would try to front a 
statement from a politician at a press conference or hearing as 
off-the-cuff.  For example, and strictly based on assumption, when Lance 
Armstrong made his statement in 2003, I doubt he had much influence in 
crafting it.  In fact, I would go one further and bet that it was written 
by a spin doctor who made a conscious effort to use disassociative language 
to distance Lance from the PED story in our minds, not necessarily Lance 
trying to distance himself sub-consciously.
comments.author: Hadrian Rex

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Ravi Sharma Convoluted phrasing is when you use too many words to say a 
simple idea. The extra words do not add anything to the idea behind the lie.
A simple explanation would be when the person avoids complex decision 
making in their story. 
So the idea is simple, but how they say it is complex. But these are not 
rules of thumb. Sometimes they can conflict, as with the simple example.

comments.text:
+isgdre Semantics. Assuming only one God does exist, what's to say that 
each person's perception of God is different, but they're both referring to 
and believe in the same god? There are many different creeds and sects that 
believe in the Bible, but they all have at least *some* differing 
interpretations of some parts of scripture, and the have differing tenets 
that they focus on. What if the god of Islam is the same as the god of 
Christianity, in the end, but people are bickering over minutiae?

comments.text:
+kenbefound Belief (source: merriam-webster)

Middle English beleave, probably alteration of Old English gelēafa, from 
ge-, associative prefix + lēafa; akin to Old English lȳfan — more at 
believe

Believe

Middle English beleven, from Old English belēfan, from be- + lȳfan, lēfan 
to allow, believe; akin to Old High German gilouben to believe, Old English 
lēof dear — more at love

Love

Middle English, from Old English lufu; akin to Old High German luba love, 
Old English lēof dear, Latin lubēre, libēre to please

Well that's an interesting twist. I never would have thought that belief is 
somehow related to love.

Point is if you are going to point through etymology at least have the 
semblance of a research. It's just one click away anyway. Etymology is 
already not a good way to argue the meaning of a word since the meaning of 
a word can change drastically over time. Moreover, pointing out that a word 
is related to another word simply because it used a similar series of 
letters doesn't really hold much water. It can be fun though, uranus - 
anus. core - ore, coincidence - den. think - thin. studying - dying, oh 
look there is stud too. Are those something to think about? For me, no.If 
you will then you'll be wasting a lot of time and effort doing it with each 
and every word - At least that I am sure of.

And for the sake of argument let's assume that "lie" in belief has meaning. 
Are you trying to insinuate that all beliefs are lies?

If yes then your belief that beliefs are lies is a lie in itself because 
saying yes to such a question is a belief in the first place.

Simply put, by stating that all beliefs are lies, then you are also stating 
that the statement that all beliefs are lies is a lie. I wonder if you will 
read this, hopefully you will.
comments.author: Federico Soriano

comments.text:
Remember, at the core of belief is the word lie "be-lie-f". Coincidence? 
Not sure, but something to think about...
comments.author: kenbefound

comments.text:
+Gemelo Samurai I don't even know what that means.  The only reference to 
EI DSM that comes up in a Google search is an aeroplane flight route.

EDIT:  Diagnostic and Statistics Manual - El being the Spanish word for 
'The'.

I agree.  Many things that are in the DSM are basic personality traits and 
not really disorders unless you are looking at them from a biased lens. 
 For example - Schizoid Personality Disorder (which I've also been labelled 
with) is pretty common for people who fall into the INTP category on the 
Meyer's Briggs - Avoiding superficial emotions because they are superficial 
and meaningless.

If an INTP wrote the DSM - what people consider 'normal' emotional 
behaviour would be 'hyper-emotional'.  It's all about frame of reference. 
 _Most_ good psychologists know this, however.  I was never told my 
Schizoid or Obessive-Compulsive Disorders were a problem *UNLESS* they were 
interfering with doing something that would improve my quality of life.

Cake is also a lie, FWIW.
comments.author: Justin White

comments.author: Gemelo Samurai

comments.text:
+Read_My_Feels991  "I think" before stating a fact is very common OCPD 
behaviour.  I notice I tend to do it when I'm uncertain if what I'm saying 
is *actually* the truth, or if its just some nonsense I picked up at random 
along the way (much of my knowledge is - I have enough smart people 
following me that they call me on my shit when I do that on G+ though!  +Gord 
Birch being one of them.)

Also, I have this strange belief that saying "I think" makes me come across 
as less of a know-it-all, rather than coming out and directly saying that 
something is so.   After asking my friends about it - apparently it doesn't.

I'm not a psychologist - but you *may* be OCPD if you tend to also obsess 
about rules and order and proper structure and procedure.  I'm told my OCPD 
is a behaviour I picked up as a child that no longer benefits me as an 
adult.  Something along the lines of "If I'm a good little boy I won't get 
in trouble, and in order to be a good little boy I have to follow the 
rules."  

I'm just reminded of the character Elsa from *Frozen* - pretty much exactly 
that.  Minus the ice magic. 

I've been working on it, it's no longer as bad as it was (I've learned to 
bite my lip when playing social games and not get all 'rules lawyery' in a 
way that interferes with fun.)
comments.author: Justin White

comments.text:
+Justin White I agree. Often people become annoyed with me because I will 
add a large amount of caveats to my wording or I will ask for clarification 
in order to be as specific as possible. The nicest way I've had this put is 
that I'm a very literal person, when in truth, I just abhor making 
inferences about subjects I could be wrong on. I've had many the college 
professor tell me I should stop saying "I think" before stating a fact.
comments.author: Read_My_Feels991

comments.text: +Justin White I do fully agree
comments.author: Gord Birch

comments.text:
#4 can trip you up.  If you are dealing with someone with Obsessive 
Compulsive Personality Disordered - they are so adverse to lying that they 
will often use convoluted phrasing to make sure their statements are 
factually accurate (or, at least, I do - and I'm told that this is typical 
of people with OCPD)

For example - they avoid absolutes, and rarely give a simple 'yes' or 'no' 
answer.  They will say "To the best of my knowledge..." or pad their 
statements with things like "This *tends to* be the case that..."

People using lingustic analysis will often believe someone with OCPD is 
lying and dodging the direct question - when, in fact, the person with OCPD 
is doing everything they can to be 100% truthful and consistent (because 
that's part of their compulsion to rules and order)  

I find it especially difficult when *compelled* to tell the truth.  I would 
be a nervous wreck if I'm testifying in court because I don't know if what 
I experienced is actually what happened but I can only speak to my 
experiences!  Example:  Identifying a suspect - "The man that I saw looked 
like the defendant."  I cannot say he was the defendant - he may have an 
identical twin brother for all I know.  Or he could have been a 
doppelgänger - all I know is that it looked like him.

I might be inclined to say "Beyond reasonable doubt - I saw the defendant" 
because that excludes things like doppelgängers - but you see where the 
phrasing starts getting convoluted.
comments.author: Justin White

top_comment.text:
Don't you think that ''communication science'' is way too subjective to 
qualify as ''science''?﻿
top_comment.author: akash parvatikar

comments.text:
Yeah but again with humans being diverse not all of ones body language can 
be interpreted as lying.
Something common is scratching of the face, lack of eye contact, etc.
comments.author: Jason Case

comments.text: +Jason Case basic communications stuff. :)
comments.author: John Morgan

comments.text:
Some culture has a norm to not look at the eyes of the person your talking 
to. This can be misinterpreted to be lying when again it's a variation of 
culture norms. 
So not all signs pointing toward lying will be will fit all situations. If 
it did there would be no variation, and studying signs of lying would be 
non existent.
comments.author: Jason Case

comments.text: If it has quantifiable results, it's a science.
comments.author: Tony Gonzales

comments.text: You're welcome
comments.author: John Morgan

comments.text:
+John Morgan Thank you so much!
The explanation I wanted to make but didn't have the time or ability to. 
Wait a sec and I'll save that as a Word file so I won't forget it, really 
appreciate it!
comments.author: Andy Flow [Music Producer]

comments.text:
I think what Andy flow was saying by theorizing table is that there are 
still some significant gaps in our knowledge. Dark Matter, UV light 
imbalances, Gravitational waves ( did we ever do follow up on those? It's 
been a few months I think....), to name a few, but the point is not 
everything is as "hard" as we make it seem. Even physicists admit that 
things work in mathematics beautifully but in reality they look "screwy" to 
quote one. But we do know a TON and that's good. In psychology there are 
definitely hard facts. I have a text book full of them. Now if we're 
talking about being able to accurately predict systems with hundreds and 
thousands and even millions or billions of variables like a human mind, or 
even like societies? We have some insight into those as well, and often 
those predictions are ACCURATE. Because these things don't let you stop 
them, you have to observe in real time. You often can't halt "light" or 
"anti-matter" per se. If you tamper with social circumstances in the 
slightest ways you can skew your results, this happens a lot. There is 
controversy about "basic emotion" which Ekman established almost fifty 
years ago as something concrete and universal to all human beings. 
Something I would consider a science if it tests hypotheses, gathers data, 
is reproducible, is self-correcting, and makes predictions about the 
universe. No need for the hard and soft labels. Is it true that physics is 
more objective in general than psychology? There are sections of psychology 
that are basically just as solid as mathematical fact I think. Given 
physics handles objects and psychology deals specifically with subjects, I 
think it's ok.
comments.author: John Morgan

comments.text:
+Sean Jackson I was skimming over this thread, but I did a "double-take" 
and read yours. Thank you. I honestly think we need to abolish the laymen 
use of the word "theory" in which it's synonymous with "hypothesis." Every 
time I hear it used incorrectly I cringe. Leads to so many great ideas 
being dismissed (popular example being evolution). Having glanced over the 
these comments, we also need to come up with terms to better 
distinguish/categorize "soft science" and "hard science."
comments.author: KoiFish

comments.text:
Social sciences have existed for what, 100-200 years? Where as physics has 
been present since Antiquity. Give it some time. Thats like asking a 1 year 
old to do algebra.
comments.author: GsusxChrist

comments.text:
+John Smith I really agree with you, psychology is a difficult science in 
that, and there needs to be so much more research to prove even basic 
things because of that, but the fact that "we aren't there yet", doesn't 
mean we'll never be, and that's why it's kind of hard for me to dismiss it 
anymore as not being a science, I see it more as a challenge.
Yea you can test. Operationalizing is more difficult here but it can be 
done. 
We're also approaching the philosophy of knowledge and truth here and it 
can be messy.   =D
comments.author: Andy Flow [Music Producer]

comments.text:
+Andy Flow
yes sure but the reason why psychology can be hardly considered an actual 
or "hard" science is because you can't really test out SHIT in a way that 
you could actually pin it down as the actual explanation because you can 
still interpret any correlation in so many different ways that don't even 
necessarily have anything in common with each other and this may occur 
sometimes  in other sciences but not ONE as much as in psychology which is 
basically everything that psychology has a theory on...
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+Sean Jackson We're not arguing about the definition of a theory here and 
you should know that, it was pretty obvious from the context what I meant. 
Also, if you actually googled "theory", you'd see that that definition of 
theory of yours is a little too specific and isn't in widespread use as 
such. I was also not meaning hypothesis, which certainly isn't "just a 
unproven theory". To cite from the wikipedia (I recommend the site 
cordially)

"A theory provides an explanatory framework for some observation, and from 
the assumptions of the explanation follows a number of possible hypotheses 
that can be tested in order to provide support for, or challenge, the 
theory."
comments.author: Andy Flow [Music Producer]

comments.text: too much yadda yadda + too little hard proof = not science.
comments.author: Cosmonauteable

comments.text:
+Andy Flow
Well, i think you already guessed it :D
That's really not my name. I just took the most common name i could think 
off and used as a pseudonym also it was actually inspired by an anime i 
watched a while ago so i took it out of nostalgic reasons ^_^
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+Sean Jackson I think that's an overgeneralization that shouldn't be made, 
as I said, it depends on the specific subject at hand. For example, you 
can't really speak of physical astronomy to be "objectively hard" when 
we're still at the theorizing table. We can't acquire too much objective 
knowledge from black holes or such, but we can quite easily test 
behaviorism theories (at least on animals), which is a part of psychology.
Still, I do see your point.
comments.author: Andy Flow [Music Producer]

comments.text: +Sean Jackson Yeah, I can live with that.
comments.author: akash parvatikar

comments.text:
+John Smith 
Well, at least when looking through the lens of neurobiology you begin to 
feel like classical psychology is a science that finds phenomena about how 
we work and then you explain it through biology, but sometimes it's too 
hard or complex so you need to go a little abstract. Then you begin to 
theorize but that isn't far from being scientific either, there are just 
some things you can't test for yet with current technology.  

Also, is John Smith your actual name? =D
comments.author: Andy Flow [Music Producer]

comments.text:
+Andy Flow
really? what *did* change your mind?
I'm still unable to give psychology any recognition regarding being a 
science, so it would be helpful to know a reason that could change my mind 
or view about it
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
Depends on the specific subject at hand, I used to think that of 
psychology, but my mind has changed quite a bit.
comments.author: Andy Flow [Music Producer]

top_comment.text:
This is misleading.
The three situations that the narrator has described are universal; almost 
anyone, lying or not, may utilize the "convoluted[ity]" in speech. A more 
direct look at the video reveals contradicting claims. How can a supposedly 
liar speak in "simple terms" like "I did not have sexual relations with 
thay woman" while also speaking in "convoluted" terms? The producer is 
basically making a claim that "liars" speak; he described the only two 
complexity at which a person can speak.
I am not, however, rejecting the validity of linguistic text analysis for 
an analysis in speech in explicit context can reveal one's truthfulness. I 
am merely suggesting that viewers should not use the extremely generic 
cases explained in the video as a guideline in determining another's 
truthfulness in very specific context.﻿
top_comment.author: Kevin Loo

comments.text:
I recall Reading on ehow that whether someone is lying has to be evaluated 
on a case by case situation. So not all signs that fit in situation a will 
show that person in situation b is lying.
comments.author: Jason Case

comments.text:
Being overly simple, or being convoluted, are two opposite extremes. Our 
goal in language is to be precise and concise, and neither extreme 
accomplishes this. We should only use as many words as necessary, no more, 
no less. People tend to be better at this when they're telling the truth.
comments.author: D Sab

For your average politician it is fairly easy: if their lips move, they are

top_comment.text:
I don't know, public and political statements are not a good example to 
analyze imo. They are usually engineered in a specific way by public 
relations personnel or lawyers so there is little of the person saying it 
in them. Taking a complex structure as a sign of a lie in that context does 
not seem to be that compelling, since any and every legal statement for 
instance follows such a structure in order not to leave any variable 
unaddressed.﻿

comments.text:
Yeah, I agree, in politics specifically you must try to be careful with

captions.text: "Sorry, my phone died."
"It's nothing. I'm fine."

"These allegations
are completely unfounded."

"The company was not aware
of any wrongdoing."
"I love you."

We hear anywhere
from 10 to 200 lies a day,

and we spent much of our history
coming up with ways to detect them,

from medieval torture
devices to polygraphs,

blood-pressure and breathing monitors,
voice-stress analyzers,
eye trackers, infrared brain scanners,

and even the 400-pound
electroencephalogram.

But although such tools have worked
under certain circumstances,

most can be fooled
with enough preparation,

and none are considered reliable enough
to even be admissible in court.

But, what if the problem
is not with the techniques,

but the underlying assumption
that lying spurs physiological changes?
What if we took a more direct approach,

using communication science
to analyze the lies themselves?

On a psychological level, we lie partly
to paint a better picture of ourselves,

connecting our fantasies
to the person we wish we were
rather than the person we are.

But while our brain is busy dreaming,
it's letting plenty of signals slip by.

Our conscious mind only controls
about 5% of our cognitive function,
including communication,

while the other 95% occurs
beyond our awareness,

and according to the literature
on reality monitoring,
stories based on imagined experiences

are qualitatively different
from those based on real experiences.

This suggests that creating a false story
about a personal topic takes work

and results in a different
pattern of language use.

A technology known
as linguistic text analysis

has helped to identify
four such common patterns
in the subconscious language of deception.

First, liars reference themselves less,
when making deceptive statements.

They write or talk more about others,
often using the third person

to distance and disassociate
themselves from their lie,
which sounds more false:

"Absolutely no party took
place at this house,"
or "I didn't host a party here."
Second, liars tend to be more negative,

because on a subconscious level,
they feel guilty about lying.

For example, a liar
might say something like,

"Sorry, my stupid phone battery died.
I hate that thing."

Third, liars typically explain
events in simple terms

since our brains struggle
to build a complex lie.
Judgment and evaluation

are complex things
for our brains to compute.

As a U.S. President once
famously insisted:

"I did not have sexual relations
with that woman."

And finally, even though liars
keep descriptions simple,

they tend to use longer
and more convoluted sentence structure,
inserting unnecessary words

and irrelevant but factual
sounding details in order to pad the lie.

Another President confronted
with a scandal proclaimed:

"I can say, categorically,
that this investigation indicates
that no one on the White House staff,

no one in this administration
presently employed

was involved
in this very bizarre incident."

Let's apply linguistic analysis
to some famous examples.

Take seven-time Tour de France
winner Lance Armstrong.
When comparing a 2005 interview,

in which he had denied taking
performance-enhancing drugs

to a 2013 interview,
in which he admitted it,

his use of personal pronouns
increased by nearly 3/4.

Note the contrast
between the following two quotes.

First: "Okay, you know, a guy
in a French, in a Parisian laboratory

opens up your sample, you know,
Jean-Francis so-and-so, and he tests it.

And then you get a phone call
from a newspaper that says:

'We found you to be positive
six times for EPO."
Second: "I lost myself in all of that.

I'm sure there would be other people
that couldn't handle it,
but I certainly couldn't handle it,

and I was used to controlling
everything in my life.
I controlled every outcome in my life."

In his denial, Armstrong described
a hypothetical situation
focused on someone else,

removing himself
from the situation entirely.
In his admission, he owns his statements,

delving into his personal emotions
and motivations.

But the use of personal pronouns
is just one indicator of deception.

Let's look at another example
from former Senator

and U.S. Presidential candidate
John Edwards:

"I only know that the apparent
father has said publicly
that he is the father of the baby.

I also have not been engaged
in any activity of any description

that requested, agreed to,
or supported payments of any kind

to the woman or to the apparent
father of the baby."

Not only is that a pretty long-winded way
to say, "The baby isn't mine,"

but Edwards never calls
the other parties by name,

instead saying "that baby," "the woman,"
and "the apparent father."

Now let's see what he had to say
when later admitting paternity:
"I am Quinn's father.

I will do everything
in my power to provide her
with the love and support she deserves."
The statement is short and direct,

calling the child by name
and addressing his role in her life.

So how can you apply these
lie-spotting techniques to your life?

First, remember that many of the lies
we encounter on a daily basis

are far less serious that these examples,
and may even be harmless.

But it's still worthwhile
to be aware of telltale clues,

like minimal self-references,
negative language,

simple explanations
and convoluted phrasing.

It just might help you avoid
an overvalued stock,

an ineffective product,
or even a terrible relationship.

title: The language of lying - Noah Zandan
